Context:
This table is about the section A1.1 Overview > User Interface. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = No.; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 2, column 1 = (1); row 2, column 2 = ToolbarProvides expression editing features such as Undo/Redo, Find, and Bookmark in a toolbar format for convenient access.; row 3, column 1 = (2); row 3, column 2 = Expression Editing WindowThis is where expressions are edited. Users can enter expressions manually or use tools (4) ~ (8) to edit them. By using these tools, expressions used in ECMiner™ can be easily edited through mouse operations.; row 4, column 1 = (3); row 4, column 2 = Available VariablesDisplays the list of existing variables available in the current node. Select the variable you wish to use and double-click it to add it to the editing window. When added, it appears enclosed in curly braces (e.g., {DATE}), indicating that it represents a variable.; row 5, column 1 = (4); row 5, column 2 = IF StatementClicking the IF Statement button to insert the IF ~ THEN ~ ELSE ~ ENDIF statement into the expression.
table_html:
No. Description
(1) ToolbarProvides expression editing features such as Undo/Redo, Find, and Bookmark in a toolbar format for convenient access.
(2) Expression Editing WindowThis is where expressions are edited. Users can enter expressions manually or use tools (4) ~ (8) to edit them. By using these tools, expressions used in ECMiner™ can be easily edited through mouse operations.
(3) Available VariablesDisplays the list of existing variables available in the current node. Select the variable you wish to use and double-click it to add it to the editing window. When added, it appears enclosed in curly braces (e.g., {DATE}), indicating that it represents a variable.
(4) IF StatementClicking the IF Statement button to insert the IF ~ THEN ~ ELSE ~ ENDIF statement into the expression.
(5) Edit ToolClick the Edit Tool button to open the function category panel on the right.
(6) Function CategoryAllows users to choose from the provided function categories, including Transformation, Math/Trigonometric, Text, Date/Time, Variable Statistics, and Information functions. When the category is changed, the list of corresponding functions appears in section (4).
(7) Function List Displays functions belonging to the selected function category. To insert a function, double-click or press the Add button to insert it into the Expression Editing Window. The usage and a brief description of the selected function appear in section (8).
(8) Function DescriptionDisplays a brief description and usage information of the currently selected function.
(9) Numeric and Symbol ButtonsProvides frequently used numbers and symbols as buttons for quick editing using mouse operations. Clicking a button inserts the corresponding number or symbol into the editing window.
(10) Syntax CheckChecks whether the current expression syntax is valid. If an error is detected, an error message is displayed, allowing users to identify and correct the mistake.
(11) Saving and Loading Expressions You can save the current expression or open a previously saved one for reuse. Clicking the Clear button deletes all expressions currently entered. The file extension for the expressions is *.eaf
(12) Confirm or Cancel Applies or cancels the current expression input. Clicking the OK button enters the expression after performing syntax validation.If an invalid expression is entered, the program may not function properly.

Context:
This table is about the section A1.1 Overview > Toolbar. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = ICON; row 1, column 2 = Toolbar; row 1, column 3 = Description; row 2, column 1 = [image:rId10]; row 2, column 2 = Undo (Crtl+Z); row 2, column 3 = Cancel the last operation.; row 3, column 1 = [image:rId11]; row 3, column 2 = Redo (Ctrl+Y); row 3, column 3 = Redo the previously undone operation.; row 4, column 1 = [image:rId12]; row 4, column 2 = Toggle Line Numbers; row 4, column 3 = Displays or hides line numbers.; row 5, column 1 = [image:rId13]; row 5, column 2 = Toggle Column Indicator; row 5, column 3 = Displays or hides indentation guides
table_html:
ICON Toolbar Description
[image:rId10] Undo (Crtl+Z) Cancel the last operation.
[image:rId11] Redo (Ctrl+Y) Redo the previously undone operation.
[image:rId12] Toggle Line Numbers Displays or hides line numbers.
[image:rId13] Toggle Column Indicator Displays or hides indentation guides
[image:rId14] Toggle Unprint Characters Displays or hides spaces, tabs, and line break symbol. [image:rId15]
[image:rId16] Toggle Wordwrap Enables or disables automatic line wrapping. When word wrap is enabled, the horizontal scrollbar is hidden. [image:rId17]
[image:rId18] Toggle Folding Enables or disables code folding.
[image:rId19] Find (Ctrl+F) Searches for or replaces specified text. [image:rId20]
[image:rId21] Find Next (F3) Finds the next specified text.
[image:rId22] Find Previous (Shift+F3) Finds the previous specified text.
[image:rId23] Go to line (Ctrl+G) Moves the cursor to the specified line number. [image:rId24]
[image:rId25] Bookmark Setup (Ctrl+F2) Enables or disables bookmarks on the current line.[image:rId26]

Context:
This table is about the section A1.2 Function Category > Function Category. 
Title: Function Category 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Category; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 2, column 1 = Transformation; row 2, column 2 = Convert the type of a value — for example, from date to string or from string to numeric.; row 3, column 1 = Math/Trig; row 3, column 2 = Include trigonometric and mathematical functions such as sin, cos, etc.; row 4, column 1 = Text; row 4, column 2 = Functions used to process string-type data.; row 5, column 1 = Date/Time; row 5, column 2 = Extract values such as year, date, or time from date-type data.
table_html:
Category Description
Transformation Convert the type of a value — for example, from date to string or from string to numeric.
Math/Trig Include trigonometric and mathematical functions such as sin, cos, etc.
Text Functions used to process string-type data.
Date/Time Extract values such as year, date, or time from date-type data.
Variable Statistics Used to obtain basic statistical quantities depending on the type (continuous or discrete) of the currently used variable.
Information Return information about the state or type of an input value.
Record Function Perform statistical processing at the record level.
Macro Provides predefined macros (prefixed with “@”) that can be used to reference system information, iteration counts, or record-level values during expression calculation.
Other Functions Additional functions implemented based on specific requirements.

Context:
This table is about the section A1.3 Transformation. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Return Value; row 1, column 4 = Example; row 2, column 1 = ASC(text); row 2, column 2 = Returns the ASCII code value of the first character in the input string.; row 2, column 3 = Real type; row 2, column 4 = ASC("ABC") → 65; row 3, column 1 = CHR(num); row 3, column 2 = Returns the character corresponding to the given ASCII code.; row 3, column 3 = String type; row 3, column 4 = CHR(65) → "A"; row 4, column 1 = DATETOSTR(date); row 4, column 2 = Converts a date-type value to a string.; row 4, column 3 = String type; row 4, column 4 = DATETOSTR(#2004-1-1#) → "20040101"; row 5, column 1 = FLOAT(num); row 5, column 2 = Converts an integer to a real number.; row 5, column 3 = Real type; row 5, column 4 = FLOAT(3.4) → 3
table_html:
Function Name Description Return Value Example
ASC(text) Returns the ASCII code value of the first character in the input string. Real type ASC("ABC") → 65
CHR(num) Returns the character corresponding to the given ASCII code. String type CHR(65) → "A"
DATETOSTR(date) Converts a date-type value to a string. String type DATETOSTR(#2004-1-1#) → "20040101"
FLOAT(num) Converts an integer to a real number. Real type FLOAT(3.4) → 3
IIF(cond, expr1, expr2) Evaluates and returns expr1 if the condition is true; otherwise, returns expr2. Unknown IIF(1>0, 1+2, 1+3) → 3
INT(num) Converts a real number to an integer by truncating the decimal part. Integer type INT(2.371) → 2
STR(num[, num1[, num2]]) Converts a number to a string. num1 specifies the maximum length, and num2 specifies the number of decimal places. String type STR(123.345, 6, 2) → "123.35"
STRTODATE(text, fmt) Converts a string to a date-type value according to the specified format (fmt). Format symbols: y (year), m (month), d (day), H (hour), M (minute), S (second). Date type STRTODATE("2004-01-01 11:50", "yyyy-mm-dd HH:MM") → #2004-01-01 11:50:00#
VAL(text) Converts a string to a numeric value. Real type VAL("123") → 123

Format symbols: y (year), m (month), d (day), H (hour), M (minute), S (second).; row 9, column 3 = Date type; row 9, column 4 = STRTODATE("2004-01-01 11:50", "yyyy-mm-dd HH:MM") → #2004-01-01 11:50:00#; row 10, column 1 = VAL(text); row 10, column 2 = Converts a string to a numeric value.; row 10, column 3 = Real type; row 10, column 4 = VAL("123") → 123
table_html:
Function Name Description Return Value Example
ASC(text) Returns the ASCII code value of the first character in the input string. Real type ASC("ABC") → 65
CHR(num) Returns the character corresponding to the given ASCII code. String type CHR(65) → "A"
DATETOSTR(date) Converts a date-type value to a string. String type DATETOSTR(#2004-1-1#) → "20040101"
FLOAT(num) Converts an integer to a real number. Real type FLOAT(3.4) → 3
IIF(cond, expr1, expr2) Evaluates and returns expr1 if the condition is true; otherwise, returns expr2. Unknown IIF(1>0, 1+2, 1+3) → 3
INT(num) Converts a real number to an integer by truncating the decimal part. Integer type INT(2.371) → 2
STR(num[, num1[, num2]]) Converts a number to a string. num1 specifies the maximum length, and num2 specifies the number of decimal places. String type STR(123.345, 6, 2) → "123.35"
STRTODATE(text, fmt) Converts a string to a date-type value according to the specified format (fmt). Format symbols: y (year), m (month), d (day), H (hour), M (minute), S (second). Date type STRTODATE("2004-01-01 11:50", "yyyy-mm-dd HH:MM") → #2004-01-01 11:50:00#
VAL(text) Converts a string to a numeric value. Real type VAL("123") → 123

Context:
This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example; row 2, column 1 = ABS(num); row 2, column 2 = Returns the absolute value.; row 2, column 3 = ABS(-123) → 123; row 3, column 1 = ACOS(num); row 3, column 2 = Returns arccosine in radians (0 to π).; row 3, column 3 = ACOS(-0.5) → 2.09440 (2π/3); row 4, column 1 = ACOSH(num); row 4, column 2 = Returns inverse hyperbolic cosine.; row 4, column 3 = ACOSH(2) → 1.31696; row 5, column 1 = ASIN(num); row 5, column 2 = Returns arcsine in radians (−π/2 to π/2).; row 5, column 3 = ASIN(-0.5) → -0.52360 (−π/6)
table_html:
Function Name Description Example
ABS(num) Returns the absolute value. ABS(-123) → 123
ACOS(num) Returns arccosine in radians (0 to π). ACOS(-0.5) → 2.09440 (2π/3)
ACOSH(num) Returns inverse hyperbolic cosine. ACOSH(2) → 1.31696
ASIN(num) Returns arcsine in radians (−π/2 to π/2). ASIN(-0.5) → -0.52360 (−π/6)
ASINH(num) Returns inverse hyperbolic sine. ASINH(2) → 1.44364
ATAN(num) Returns arctangent in radians (−π/2 to π/2). ATAN(1) → 0.78540 (π/4)
ATAN2(num1, num2) Arctangent of (y, x), radians in (−π, π]. ATAN2(1, 1) → 0.78540 (π/4)
ATANH(num1) Returns inverse hyperbolic tangent. ATANH(0.2) → 0.20273
BETACDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETACDF(2, 2, 1) → 1.0
BETAINV(num1, num2, num3) Inverse Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at prob num3. BETAINV(2, 2, 1) → 1.0
BETAMEAN(num1, num2) Mean of Beta distribution (num1, num2). BETAMEAN(2, 2) → 0.5
BETAPDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta PDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETAPDF(2, 2, 1) → 0
BETAVARIANCE(num1, num2) Variance of Beta distribution. BETAVARIANCE(2, 2) → 0.05
BINOCDF(n, p, k) Binomial CDF with (n, p) at k. BINOCDF(4, 0.3, 3) → 0.9919
BINOINV(n, p, q) Inverse Binomial CDF (n, p) at prob q. BINOINV(4, 0.3, 0.9919) → 3
BINOMEAN(n, p) Mean of Binomial (n, p). BINOMEAN(10, 0.5) → 5
BINOPDF(n, p, k) Binomial PDF with (n, p) at k. BINOPDF(4, 0.3, 3) → 0.07560
BINOVARIANCE(n, p) Variance of Binomial. BINOVARIANCE(10, 0.5) → 2.5
CEILING(num) Smallest integer ≥ num. CEILING(2.1) → 3
CEILING2(num1, num2) Rounds num1 up to a multiple of num2. CEILING2(6.4) → 8
CHICDF(v, x) Chi-square CDF (df=v) at x. CHICDF(1, 0.3) → 0.41612
CHIINV(v, q) Inverse Chi-square CDF (df=v) at prob q. CHIINV(1, 0.41612) → 0.3
CHIMEAN(v) Mean of Chi-square with df v. CHIMEAN(10) → 10
CHIPDF(v, x) Chi-square PDF (df=v) at x. CHIPDF(1, 0.3) → 0.62691
CHIVARIANCE(v) Variance of Chi-square with df v. CHIVARIANCE(10) → 20
COMB(n, k) Number of combinations “n choose k”. COMB(4, 2) → 6
COS(rad) Returns cosine. COS(1.047) → 0.50017
COSH(num) Returns hyperbolic cosine. COSH(4) → 27.30823
DEGREE(rad) Converts radians to degrees. DEGREE(3.14159265) → 180
DIGAMMA(num) Digamma function (derivative of lgamma). DIGAMMA(1) → -0.57722
ERF(num) Error function. ERF(1) → 0.8427
ERFC(num) Complementary error function. ERFC(1) → 0.15776
EVEN(num) Rounds up to the nearest even integer. EVEN(1.5) → 2
EVCDF(mu, sigma, x) Extreme value (Gumbel) CDF at x. EVCDF(0, 1, 0.4) → 0.77504
EVINV(mu, sigma, q) Inverse extreme value CDF at prob q. EVINV(0, 1, 0.77504) → 0.40001
EVMEAN(mu, sigma) Mean of extreme value distribution. EVMEAN(0, 1) → 0.57722
EVPDF(mu, sigma, x) Extreme value PDF at x. EVPDF(0, 1, 0.4) → 0.3356
EVVARIANCE(mu, sigma) Variance of extreme value distribution. EVVARIANCE(0, 1) → 1.64493
EXP(num) Computes e^num. EXP(1) → 2.71828
EXPCDF(λ, x) Exponential CDF (rate λ) at x. EXPCDF(1, 0.4) → 0.32968
EXPINV(λ, q) Inverse Exponential CDF at prob q. EXPINV(1, 0.32968) → 0.4
EXPMEAN(λ) Mean of Exponential (1/λ or as defined). EXPMEAN(10) → 10
EXPPDF(λ, x) Exponential PDF at x. EXPPDF(1, 0.4) → 0.67032
EXPVARIANCE(λ) Variance of Exponential. EXPVARIANCE(10) → 100
FACT(num) Factorial. FACT(4) → 24
FISHER(z) Fisher transform. FISHER(0.5) → 0.54931
FISHERINV(y) Inverse Fisher transform. FISHERINV(0.54931) → 0.5
FLOOR(num) Greatest integer ≤ num. FLOOR(2.1) → 2

Context:
This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example 
Rows: row 6, column 1 = ASINH(num); row 6, column 2 = Returns inverse hyperbolic sine.; row 6, column 3 = ASINH(2) → 1.44364; row 7, column 1 = ATAN(num); row 7, column 2 = Returns arctangent in radians (−π/2 to π/2).; row 7, column 3 = ATAN(1) → 0.78540 (π/4); row 8, column 1 = ATAN2(num1, num2); row 8, column 2 = Arctangent of (y, x), radians in (−π, π].; row 8, column 3 = ATAN2(1, 1) → 0.78540 (π/4); row 9, column 1 = ATANH(num1); row 9, column 2 = Returns inverse hyperbolic tangent.; row 9, column 3 = ATANH(0.2) → 0.20273; row 10, column 1 = BETACDF(num1, num2, num3); row 10, column 2 = Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3.; row 10, column 3 = BETACDF(2, 2, 1) → 1.0
table_html:
Function Name Description Example
ABS(num) Returns the absolute value. ABS(-123) → 123

ATAN(num) Returns arctangent in radians (−π/2 to π/2). ATAN(1) → 0.78540 (π/4)

ATANH(num1) Returns inverse hyperbolic tangent. ATANH(0.2) → 0.20273
BETACDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETACDF(2, 2, 1) → 1.0

BETAMEAN(num1, num2) Mean of Beta distribution (num1, num2). BETAMEAN(2, 2) → 0.5
BETAPDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta PDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETAPDF(2, 2, 1) → 0
BETAVARIANCE(num1, num2) Variance of Beta distribution. BETAVARIANCE(2, 2) → 0.05

This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example

Function Name Description Example
ABS(num) Returns the absolute value. ABS(-123) → 123

ATANH(num1) Returns inverse hyperbolic tangent. ATANH(0.2) → 0.20273
BETACDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETACDF(2, 2, 1) → 1.0

Context:
This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example 
Rows: row 36, column 1 = EVINV(mu, sigma, q); row 36, column 2 = Inverse extreme value CDF at prob q.; row 36, column 3 = EVINV(0, 1, 0.77504) → 0.40001; row 37, column 1 = EVMEAN(mu, sigma); row 37, column 2 = Mean of extreme value distribution.; row 37, column 3 = EVMEAN(0, 1) → 0.57722; row 38, column 1 = EVPDF(mu, sigma, x); row 38, column 2 = Extreme value PDF at x.; row 38, column 3 = EVPDF(0, 1, 0.4) → 0.3356; row 39, column 1 = EVVARIANCE(mu, sigma); row 39, column 2 = Variance of extreme value distribution.; row 39, column 3 = EVVARIANCE(0, 1) → 1.64493; row 40, column 1 = EXP(num); row 40, column 2 = Computes e^num.; row 40, column 3 = EXP(1) → 2.71828

Context:
This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example 
Rows: row 41, column 1 = EXPCDF(λ, x); row 41, column 2 = Exponential CDF (rate λ) at x.; row 41, column 3 = EXPCDF(1, 0.4) → 0.32968; row 42, column 1 = EXPINV(λ, q); row 42, column 2 = Inverse Exponential CDF at prob q.; row 42, column 3 = EXPINV(1, 0.32968) → 0.4; row 43, column 1 = EXPMEAN(λ); row 43, column 2 = Mean of Exponential (1/λ or as defined).; row 43, column 3 = EXPMEAN(10) → 10; row 44, column 1 = EXPPDF(λ, x); row 44, column 2 = Exponential PDF at x.; row 44, column 3 = EXPPDF(1, 0.4) → 0.67032; row 45, column 1 = EXPVARIANCE(λ); row 45, column 2 = Variance of Exponential.; row 45, column 3 = EXPVARIANCE(10) → 100

Context:
This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example 
Rows: row 56, column 1 = GAMINV(k, θ, q); row 56, column 2 = Inverse Gamma CDF at prob q.; row 56, column 3 = GAMINV(1, 2, 0.39347) → 1; row 57, column 1 = GAMMEAN(k, θ); row 57, column 2 = Mean of Gamma (kθ).; row 57, column 3 = GAMMEAN(3, 3) → 9; row 58, column 1 = GAMPDF(k, θ, x); row 58, column 2 = Gamma PDF at x.; row 58, column 3 = GAMPDF(1, 2, 1) → 0.30327; row 59, column 1 = GAMVARIANCE(k, θ); row 59, column 2 = Variance of Gamma (kθ²).; row 59, column 3 = GAMVARIANCE(3, 3) → 27; row 60, column 1 = GEOCDF(p, k); row 60, column 2 = Geometric CDF at k.; row 60, column 3 = GEOCDF(0.3, 2) → 0.657

This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example

Context:
This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example 
Rows: row 91, column 1 = NBINCDF(r, p, k); row 91, column 2 = Negative binomial CDF at k.; row 91, column 3 = NBINCDF(3, 0.5, 2) → 0.5; row 92, column 1 = NBININV(r, p, q); row 92, column 2 = Inverse negative binomial CDF at prob q.; row 92, column 3 = NBININV(3, 0.5, 0.5) → 2; row 93, column 1 = NBINMEAN(r, p); row 93, column 2 = Mean of negative binomial.; row 93, column 3 = NBINMEAN(10, 0.5) → 10; row 94, column 1 = NBINPDF(r, p, k); row 94, column 2 = Negative binomial PDF at k.; row 94, column 3 = NBINPDF(3, 0.5, 2) → 0.1875; row 95, column 1 = NBINVARIANCE(r, p); row 95, column 2 = Variance of negative binomial.; row 95, column 3 = NBINVARIANCE(10, 0.5) → 20

Function Name Description Example
ABS(num) Returns the absolute value. ABS(-123) → 123

ATANH(num1) Returns inverse hyperbolic tangent. ATANH(0.2) → 0.20273

This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example

Function Name Description Example
ABS(num) Returns the absolute value. ABS(-123) → 123
ACOS(num) Returns arccosine in radians (0 to π). ACOS(-0.5) → 2.09440 (2π/3)
ACOSH(num) Returns inverse hyperbolic cosine. ACOSH(2) → 1.31696
ASIN(num) Returns arcsine in radians (−π/2 to π/2). ASIN(-0.5) → -0.52360 (−π/6)
ASINH(num) Returns inverse hyperbolic sine. ASINH(2) → 1.44364
ATAN(num) Returns arctangent in radians (−π/2 to π/2). ATAN(1) → 0.78540 (π/4)
ATAN2(num1, num2) Arctangent of (y, x), radians in (−π, π]. ATAN2(1, 1) → 0.78540 (π/4)
ATANH(num1) Returns inverse hyperbolic tangent. ATANH(0.2) → 0.20273
BETACDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETACDF(2, 2, 1) → 1.0
BETAINV(num1, num2, num3) Inverse Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at prob num3. BETAINV(2, 2, 1) → 1.0
BETAMEAN(num1, num2) Mean of Beta distribution (num1, num2). BETAMEAN(2, 2) → 0.5
BETAPDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta PDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETAPDF(2, 2, 1) → 0
BETAVARIANCE(num1, num2) Variance of Beta distribution. BETAVARIANCE(2, 2) → 0.05
BINOCDF(n, p, k) Binomial CDF with (n, p) at k. BINOCDF(4, 0.3, 3) → 0.9919
BINOINV(n, p, q) Inverse Binomial CDF (n, p) at prob q. BINOINV(4, 0.3, 0.9919) → 3
BINOMEAN(n, p) Mean of Binomial (n, p). BINOMEAN(10, 0.5) → 5
BINOPDF(n, p, k) Binomial PDF with (n, p) at k. BINOPDF(4, 0.3, 3) → 0.07560
BINOVARIANCE(n, p) Variance of Binomial. BINOVARIANCE(10, 0.5) → 2.5
CEILING(num) Smallest integer ≥ num. CEILING(2.1) → 3
CEILING2(num1, num2) Rounds num1 up to a multiple of num2. CEILING2(6.4) → 8
CHICDF(v, x) Chi-square CDF (df=v) at x. CHICDF(1, 0.3) → 0.41612
CHIINV(v, q) Inverse Chi-square CDF (df=v) at prob q. CHIINV(1, 0.41612) → 0.3
CHIMEAN(v) Mean of Chi-square with df v. CHIMEAN(10) → 10
CHIPDF(v, x) Chi-square PDF (df=v) at x. CHIPDF(1, 0.3) → 0.62691
CHIVARIANCE(v) Variance of Chi-square with df v. CHIVARIANCE(10) → 20
COMB(n, k) Number of combinations “n choose k”. COMB(4, 2) → 6
COS(rad) Returns cosine. COS(1.047) → 0.50017
COSH(num) Returns hyperbolic cosine. COSH(4) → 27.30823
DEGREE(rad) Converts radians to degrees. DEGREE(3.14159265) → 180
DIGAMMA(num) Digamma function (derivative of lgamma). DIGAMMA(1) → -0.57722
ERF(num) Error function. ERF(1) → 0.8427
ERFC(num) Complementary error function. ERFC(1) → 0.15776
EVEN(num) Rounds up to the nearest even integer. EVEN(1.5) → 2
EVCDF(mu, sigma, x) Extreme value (Gumbel) CDF at x. EVCDF(0, 1, 0.4) → 0.77504
EVINV(mu, sigma, q) Inverse extreme value CDF at prob q. EVINV(0, 1, 0.77504) → 0.40001
EVMEAN(mu, sigma) Mean of extreme value distribution. EVMEAN(0, 1) → 0.57722
EVPDF(mu, sigma, x) Extreme value PDF at x. EVPDF(0, 1, 0.4) → 0.3356
EVVARIANCE(mu, sigma) Variance of extreme value distribution. EVVARIANCE(0, 1) → 1.64493
EXP(num) Computes e^num. EXP(1) → 2.71828
EXPCDF(λ, x) Exponential CDF (rate λ) at x. EXPCDF(1, 0.4) → 0.32968
EXPINV(λ, q) Inverse Exponential CDF at prob q. EXPINV(1, 0.32968) → 0.4
EXPMEAN(λ) Mean of Exponential (1/λ or as defined). EXPMEAN(10) → 10
EXPPDF(λ, x) Exponential PDF at x. EXPPDF(1, 0.4) → 0.67032
EXPVARIANCE(λ) Variance of Exponential. EXPVARIANCE(10) → 100
FACT(num) Factorial. FACT(4) → 24
FISHER(z) Fisher transform. FISHER(0.5) → 0.54931
FISHERINV(y) Inverse Fisher transform. FISHERINV(0.54931) → 0.5
FLOOR(num) Greatest integer ≤ num. FLOOR(2.1) → 2
FCDF(ν1, ν2, x) F-distribution CDF at x. FCDF(2, 4, 3) → 0.84
FINV(ν1, ν2, q) Inverse F CDF at prob q. FINV(2, 4, 0.84) → 3

FVARIANCE(ν1, ν2) Variance of F distribution. FVARIANCE(5, 5) → 8.88889
GAMCDF(k, θ, x) Gamma CDF (shape k, scale θ) at x. GAMCDF(1, 2, 1) → 0.39347
GAMINV(k, θ, q) Inverse Gamma CDF at prob q. GAMINV(1, 2, 0.39347) → 1
GAMMEAN(k, θ) Mean of Gamma (kθ). GAMMEAN(3, 3) → 9
GAMPDF(k, θ, x) Gamma PDF at x. GAMPDF(1, 2, 1) → 0.30327
GAMVARIANCE(k, θ) Variance of Gamma (kθ²). GAMVARIANCE(3, 3) → 27
GEOCDF(p, k) Geometric CDF at k. GEOCDF(0.3, 2) → 0.657
GEOINV(p, q) Inverse Geometric CDF at prob q. GEOINV(0.3, 0.657) → 3
GEOMEAN(p) Mean of Geometric. GEOMEAN(0.25) → 3
GEOPDF(p, k) Geometric PDF at k. GEOPDF(0.3, 2) → 0.147
GEOVARIANCE(p) Variance of Geometric. GEOVARIANCE(0.25) → 12
GEVCDF(mu, sigma, k, x) Generalized extreme value CDF at x. GEVCDF(0,1,0,2) → 0.87342
GEVINV(mu, sigma, k, q) Inverse GEV CDF at prob q. GEVINV(0,1,0,0.87342) → 1.99997
GEVMEAN(mu, sigma, k) Mean of GEV. GEVMEAN(1,3,0.1) → 3.05886
GEVPDF(mu, sigma, k, x) GEV PDF at x. GEVPDF(0,1,0,2) → 0.1182
GEVVARIANCE(mu, sigma, k) Variance of GEV. GEVVARIANCE(1,3,0.1) → 20.03617
GPCDF(K, sigma, theta, x) Generalized Pareto CDF at x. GPCDF(0,1,0,2) → 0.86466
GPINV(K, sigma, theta, q) Inverse GP CDF at prob q. GPINV(0,1,0,0.86466) → 1.99997
GPMEAN(K, sigma, theta) Mean of GP. GPMEAN(0.1,3,1) → 4.33333
GPPDF(K, sigma, theta, x) GP PDF at x. GPPDF(0,1,0,2) → 0.13534
GPVARIANCE(K, sigma, theta) Variance of GP. GPVARIANCE(0.1,3,1) → 13.88889
HYGECDF(m, k, n, x) Hypergeometric CDF at x. HYGECDF(100,20,10,2) → 0.68122
HYGEINV(m, k, n, q) Inverse Hypergeometric CDF at prob q. HYGEINV(100,20,10,0.68122) → 2
HYGEMEAN(m, k, n) Mean of Hypergeometric. HYGEMEAN(10,5,4) → 2
HYGEPDF(m, k, n, x) Hypergeometric PDF at x. HYGEPDF(100,20,10,2) → 0.31817
HYGEVARIANCE(m, k, n) Variance of Hypergeometric. HYGEVARIANCE(10,5,4) → 0.66667
LGAMMA(num) Natural log of Gamma function. LGAMMA(3) → 0.69315
LN(num) Natural logarithm. LN(86) → 4.45435
LOG(num, base) Logarithm with given base. LOG(7, 2) → 2.80735
LOG10(num) Base-10 logarithm. LOG10(86) → 1.93450
LOGBETA(num1, num2) Natural log of Beta function. LOGBETA(5, 3) → -4.65396
LOGNCDF(mu, sigma, x) Lognormal CDF at x. LOGNCDF(0,1,2) → 0.75589
LOGNINV(mu, sigma, q) Inverse lognormal CDF at prob q. LOGNINV(0,1,0.75589) → 1.99999
LOGNMEAN(mu, sigma) Mean of lognormal. LOGNMEAN(-2, 2) → 1
LOGNPDF(mu, sigma, x) Lognormal PDF at x. LOGNPDF(0,1,2) → 0.15687
LOGNVARIANCE(mu, sigma) Variance of lognormal. LOGNVARIANCE(-2, 2) → 53.59815
MOD(num1, num2) Remainder of num1 / num2. MOD(5, 2) → 1
NBINCDF(r, p, k) Negative binomial CDF at k. NBINCDF(3, 0.5, 2) → 0.5
NBININV(r, p, q) Inverse negative binomial CDF at prob q. NBININV(3, 0.5, 0.5) → 2
NBINMEAN(r, p) Mean of negative binomial. NBINMEAN(10, 0.5) → 10
NBINPDF(r, p, k) Negative binomial PDF at k. NBINPDF(3, 0.5, 2) → 0.1875
NBINVARIANCE(r, p) Variance of negative binomial. NBINVARIANCE(10, 0.5) → 20
NCFCDF(ν1, ν2, δ, x) Noncentral F CDF at x. NCFCDF(5,20,10,2) → 0.2719
NCFINV(ν1, ν2, δ, q) Inverse noncentral F CDF at prob q. NCFINV(5,20,10,0.2719) → 2

NCFPDF(ν1, ν2, δ, x) Noncentral F PDF at x. NCFPDF(5,20,10,2) → 0.26075
NCFVARIANCE(ν1, ν2, δ) Variance of noncentral F. NCFVARIANCE(10,100,4) → 0.42517
NCTCDF(ν, δ, x) Noncentral t CDF at x. NCTCDF(10,1,2) → 0.80761
NCTINV(ν, δ, q) Inverse noncentral t CDF at prob q. NCTINV(10,1,0.80761) → 1.99999
NCTMEAN(ν, δ) Mean of noncentral t. NCTMEAN(4,1) → 1.25331
NCTPDF(ν, δ, x) Noncentral t PDF at x. NCTPDF(10,1,2) → 0.00006
NCTVARIANCE(ν, δ) Variance of noncentral t. NCTVARIANCE(4,1) → 2.4292
NCX2CDF(ν, δ, x) Noncentral χ² CDF at x. NCX2CDF(4,2,2) → 0.13048
NCX2INV(ν, δ, q) Inverse noncentral χ² CDF at prob q. NCX2INV(4,2,0.13048) → 2.00003
NCX2MEAN(ν, δ) Mean of noncentral χ². NCX2MEAN(4,2) → 6
NCX2PDF(ν, δ, x) Noncentral χ² PDF at x. NCX2PDF(4,2,2) → 0.10763
NCX2VARIANCE(ν, δ) Variance of noncentral χ². NCX2VARIANCE(4,2) → 16
NORMCDF(mu, sigma, x) Normal CDF at x. NORMCDF(-1,1,2) → 0.99865
NORMDIST(x, mu, sigma) Normal CDF at x (if x<mu, returns 1−CDF). NORMDIST(6,5,1) → 0.84134; NORMDIST(4,5,1) → 0.84134
NORMINV(mu, sigma, q) Inverse Normal CDF at prob q. NORMINV(-1,1,0.99865) → 1.99998
NORMMEAN(mu, sigma) Mean of Normal. NORMMEAN(0,2) → 0
NORMPDF(mu, sigma, x) Normal PDF at x. NORMPDF(-1,1,2) → 0.00443
NORMVARIANCE(mu, sigma) Variance of Normal. NORMVARIANCE(0,2) → 4
ODD(num) Rounds up to the nearest odd integer. ODD(1.1) → 3
PERM(n, k) Number of permutations. PERM(4, 2) → 12
POISCDF(λ, k) Poisson CDF at k. POISCDF(4, 2) → 0.2381
POISINV(λ, q) Inverse Poisson CDF at prob q. POISINV(4, 0.2381) → 1
POISMEAN(λ) Mean of Poisson. POISMEAN(2) → 2
POISPDF(λ, k) Poisson PDF at k. POISPDF(4, 2) → 0.14653
POISVARIANCE(λ) Variance of Poisson. POISVARIANCE(2) → 2
POWER(num1, num2) Returns num1 to the power of num2. POWER(4, 0.5) → 2
PRODUCT(num1, num2, …) Product of all arguments. PRODUCT(1, 2) → 2
RADIANS(deg) Converts degrees to radians. RADIANS(180) → 3.14159 (π)
RAND() Generates a random number between 0 and 1000. RAND() → (e.g.) 534.12
RAYLCDF(σ, x) Rayleigh CDF at x. RAYLCDF(1, 2) → 0.86466
RAYLINV(σ, q) Inverse Rayleigh CDF at prob q. RAYLINV(1, 0.86466) → 1.99998
RAYLMEAN(σ) Mean of Rayleigh. RAYLMEAN(2) → 2.50663
RAYLPDF(σ, x) Rayleigh PDF at x. RAYLPDF(1, 2) → 0.27067
RAYLVARIANCE(σ) Variance of Rayleigh. RAYLVARIANCE(2) → 1.71681
ROUND(num, digit) Rounds to digit decimal places. ROUND(12.345, 2) → 12.35
ROUNDDOWN(num, digit) Rounds down to digit places. ROUNDDOWN(2.50663, 2) → 2.50
ROUNDUP(num, digit) Rounds up to digit places. ROUNDUP(2.50663, 2) → 2.51
SIN(rad) Returns sine. SIN(3.141592) → 0
SINH(num) Returns hyperbolic sine. SINH(1) → 1.17520
SQRT(num) Positive square root. SQRT(4) → 2
TAN(rad) Returns tangent. TAN(0.785) → 0.99920
TANH(num) Returns hyperbolic tangent. TANH(-2) → -0.96403
TCDF(ν, x) Student’s t CDF at x. TCDF(1, 0.5) → 0.64758
TINV(ν, q) Inverse t CDF at prob q. TINV(1, 0.64758) → 0.49999
TMEAN(ν) Mean of t distribution. TMEAN(4) → 0
TOMAX(var, limit) Returns var if var ≤ limit, else limit. TOMAX(9,10) → 9; TOMAX(11,10) → 10
TPDF(ν, x) Student’s t PDF at x. TPDF(1, 0.5) → 0.25465
TRIGAMMA(num1) Trigamma function. TRIGAMMA(1) → 1.64493
TRUNC(num1, digit) Truncates to digit decimal places. TRUNC(0.76, 1) → 0.7
TVARIANCE(ν) Variance of t distribution. TVARIANCE(4) → 2
UNIDCDF(N, k) Discrete uniform CDF at k (1…N). UNIDCDF(50, 20) → 0.4
UNIDINV(N, q) Inverse discrete uniform CDF at prob q. UNIDINV(50, 0.4) → 20
UNIDMEAN(N) Mean of discrete uniform. UNIDMEAN(5) → 3
UNIDPDF(N, k) Discrete uniform PDF at k. UNIDPDF(50, 20) → 0.02
UNIDVARIANCE(N) Variance of discrete uniform. (example not provided)
UNIFCDF(a, b, x) Continuous uniform CDF at x. UNIFCDF(-1, 1, 0.7) → 0.85
UNIFINV(a, b, q) Inverse continuous uniform CDF at prob q. UNIFINV(-1, 1, 0.85) → 0.7
UNIFMEAN(a, b) Mean of continuous uniform. UNIFMEAN(1, 7) → 4
UNIFPDF(a, b, x) Continuous uniform PDF at x. UNIFPDF(-1, 1, 0.7) → 0.5
UNIFVARIANCE(a, b) Variance of continuous uniform. UNIFVARIANCE(1, 7) → 3
WBLCDF(k, λ, x) Weibull CDF at x. WBLCDF(0.15, 0.8, 0.5) → 0.53846
WBLINV(k, λ, q) Inverse Weibull CDF at prob q. WBLINV(0.15, 0.8, 0.53846) → 0.5
WBLMEAN(k, λ) Mean of Weibull. WBLMEAN(2, 0.5) → 4
WBLPDF(k, λ, x) Weibull PDF at x. WBLPDF(0.15, 0.8, 0.5) → 1.53846
WBLVARIANCE(k, λ) Variance of Weibull. WBLVARIANCE(2, 80) → 0.00100

Context:
This table is about the section A1.4 Math/Trig. 
Title: All of the Math/Trig functions return Real type values. 
Header candidates: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Example 
Rows: row 156, column 1 = UNIFMEAN(a, b); row 156, column 2 = Mean of continuous uniform.; row 156, column 3 = UNIFMEAN(1, 7) → 4; row 157, column 1 = UNIFPDF(a, b, x); row 157, column 2 = Continuous uniform PDF at x.; row 157, column 3 = UNIFPDF(-1, 1, 0.7) → 0.5; row 158, column 1 = UNIFVARIANCE(a, b); row 158, column 2 = Variance of continuous uniform.; row 158, column 3 = UNIFVARIANCE(1, 7) → 3; row 159, column 1 = WBLCDF(k, λ, x); row 159, column 2 = Weibull CDF at x.; row 159, column 3 = WBLCDF(0.15, 0.8, 0.5) → 0.53846; row 160, column 1 = WBLINV(k, λ, q); row 160, column 2 = Inverse Weibull CDF at prob q.; row 160, column 3 = WBLINV(0.15, 0.8, 0.53846) → 0.5

Function Name Description Example
ABS(num) Returns the absolute value. ABS(-123) → 123
ACOS(num) Returns arccosine in radians (0 to π). ACOS(-0.5) → 2.09440 (2π/3)
ACOSH(num) Returns inverse hyperbolic cosine. ACOSH(2) → 1.31696

ATAN(num) Returns arctangent in radians (−π/2 to π/2). ATAN(1) → 0.78540 (π/4)

ATANH(num1) Returns inverse hyperbolic tangent. ATANH(0.2) → 0.20273
BETACDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETACDF(2, 2, 1) → 1.0
BETAINV(num1, num2, num3) Inverse Beta CDF with shape (num1, num2) at prob num3. BETAINV(2, 2, 1) → 1.0
BETAMEAN(num1, num2) Mean of Beta distribution (num1, num2). BETAMEAN(2, 2) → 0.5
BETAPDF(num1, num2, num3) Beta PDF with shape (num1, num2) at num3. BETAPDF(2, 2, 1) → 0
BETAVARIANCE(num1, num2) Variance of Beta distribution. BETAVARIANCE(2, 2) → 0.05
BINOCDF(n, p, k) Binomial CDF with (n, p) at k. BINOCDF(4, 0.3, 3) → 0.9919

BINOMEAN(n, p) Mean of Binomial (n, p). BINOMEAN(10, 0.5) → 5
BINOPDF(n, p, k) Binomial PDF with (n, p) at k. BINOPDF(4, 0.3, 3) → 0.07560

Where x represents the number of times the compared string is repeated.; row 5, column 3 = Real type; row 5, column 4 = GETSTRCOMBINE(@{Text_Results(Morpheme)}, GETIDXSTRCMP(1, @{Text_Rreulst(Part of Speech)}, ‘NNG’, 0,1), @rownum)
table_html:
Function Name Description Return Value Example
ALLTRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes all occurrences of text2 from text1. If text2 is omitted, removes spaces. String type ALLTRIM("AABACD","A") → "BCD"
CHRTRAN(text1, text2, text3) Replaces every occurrence of text2 in text1 with text3. String type CHRTRAN("BBACD","A","C") → "BBCCD"
FIND(text1, text2[, num]) Returns the start position of the num-th occurrence of text2 in text1. (1-based index) Real type FIND("ABBACDAB","A",2) → 4
GETIDXSTRCMP([Search Direction: Up 1, Down 0], [Comparison Variable Index @{Variable Name}, [Comparison String ‘NNG’], [String Equality Condition 1, Inequality Condition 0], [Condition Repeat Satisfaction Count]] Based on the current column position, return the satisfied column positions x number of times. Where x represents the number of times the compared string is repeated. Real type GETSTRCOMBINE(@{Text_Results(Morpheme)}, GETIDXSTRCMP(1, @{Text_Rreulst(Part of Speech)}, ‘NNG’, 0,1), @rownum)
GETSTRCOMBINE([Target String Variable @{Field Name}], [Extraction Start Column], [Extraction End Column]) Return the combined characters of the specified string locations of the specified string variable. String type
KOR_GET1(text) Extracts Hangul characters from text. String type KOR_GET1("ABCㄱㄴㄷ") → "ㄱㄴㄷ"
KOR_GET2(text, num1[, num2]) From text[num1…num2] returns Hangul-only substring. If num2 omitted, goes to end. String type KOR_GET2("가나다ab라마",2,6) → "나다라마"
LEFT(text1, num) Returns the leftmost num characters of text1. String type LEFT("ABBACDAB",3) → "ABB"
LEN(text1) Returns the character length of text1. Real type LEN("ABBACDAB") → 8
LIKE(text1, text2) Returns TRUE if text1 matches the pattern text2. String type LIKE("ABBACD","*CD") → TRUE
LOWER(text1) Converts text1 to lowercase. String type LOWER("AbCD") → "abcd"
LTRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes from the left all leading characters contained in text2. String type LTRIM("AABACD","A") → "BACD"
OCCURS(text1, text2) Counts how many times text2 occurs in text1. Real type OCCURS("AABACD","A") → 3
REPT(text1, num) Repeats text1 num times. String type REPT("A",3) → "AAA"
RIGHT(text1, num) Returns the rightmost num characters of text1. String type RIGHT("AABACD",2) → "CD"
RTRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes from the right all trailing characters contained in text2. String type RTRIM("DCABAA","A") → "DCAB"
SPACE(num) Returns a string of num spaces (REPT(" ", num)). String type SPACE(3) → " "
STRSORT(text) Returns text with its characters sorted (ascending). String type STRSORT("adbc") → "abcd"
SUBSTR(text1, num1[, num2]) Returns substring starting at num1 of length num2 (or to end if omitted). String type SUBSTR("AABACD",2,3) → "ABA"
TRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes from both ends all characters contained in text2. String type TRIM("AABACDA","A") → "BACD"
UPPER(text1) Converts text1 to uppercase. String type UPPER("aaBAcD") → "AABACD"
UTF8(text1) Decodes percent-encoded UTF-8 (URL decode). String type UTF8("%EB%B9%B5") → "빵"

table_html:
Function Name Description Return Value Example
ALLTRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes all occurrences of text2 from text1. If text2 is omitted, removes spaces. String type ALLTRIM("AABACD","A") → "BCD"
CHRTRAN(text1, text2, text3) Replaces every occurrence of text2 in text1 with text3. String type CHRTRAN("BBACD","A","C") → "BBCCD"
FIND(text1, text2[, num]) Returns the start position of the num-th occurrence of text2 in text1. (1-based index) Real type FIND("ABBACDAB","A",2) → 4
GETIDXSTRCMP([Search Direction: Up 1, Down 0], [Comparison Variable Index @{Variable Name}, [Comparison String ‘NNG’], [String Equality Condition 1, Inequality Condition 0], [Condition Repeat Satisfaction Count]] Based on the current column position, return the satisfied column positions x number of times. Where x represents the number of times the compared string is repeated. Real type GETSTRCOMBINE(@{Text_Results(Morpheme)}, GETIDXSTRCMP(1, @{Text_Rreulst(Part of Speech)}, ‘NNG’, 0,1), @rownum)
GETSTRCOMBINE([Target String Variable @{Field Name}], [Extraction Start Column], [Extraction End Column]) Return the combined characters of the specified string locations of the specified string variable. String type
KOR_GET1(text) Extracts Hangul characters from text. String type KOR_GET1("ABCㄱㄴㄷ") → "ㄱㄴㄷ"
KOR_GET2(text, num1[, num2]) From text[num1…num2] returns Hangul-only substring. If num2 omitted, goes to end. String type KOR_GET2("가나다ab라마",2,6) → "나다라마"
LEFT(text1, num) Returns the leftmost num characters of text1. String type LEFT("ABBACDAB",3) → "ABB"
LEN(text1) Returns the character length of text1. Real type LEN("ABBACDAB") → 8
LIKE(text1, text2) Returns TRUE if text1 matches the pattern text2. String type LIKE("ABBACD","*CD") → TRUE
LOWER(text1) Converts text1 to lowercase. String type LOWER("AbCD") → "abcd"
LTRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes from the left all leading characters contained in text2. String type LTRIM("AABACD","A") → "BACD"
OCCURS(text1, text2) Counts how many times text2 occurs in text1. Real type OCCURS("AABACD","A") → 3
REPT(text1, num) Repeats text1 num times. String type REPT("A",3) → "AAA"
RIGHT(text1, num) Returns the rightmost num characters of text1. String type RIGHT("AABACD",2) → "CD"
RTRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes from the right all trailing characters contained in text2. String type RTRIM("DCABAA","A") → "DCAB"
SPACE(num) Returns a string of num spaces (REPT(" ", num)). String type SPACE(3) → " "
STRSORT(text) Returns text with its characters sorted (ascending). String type STRSORT("adbc") → "abcd"
SUBSTR(text1, num1[, num2]) Returns substring starting at num1 of length num2 (or to end if omitted). String type SUBSTR("AABACD",2,3) → "ABA"
TRIM(text1[, text2]) Removes from both ends all characters contained in text2. String type TRIM("AABACDA","A") → "BACD"
UPPER(text1) Converts text1 to uppercase. String type UPPER("aaBAcD") → "AABACD"
UTF8(text1) Decodes percent-encoded UTF-8 (URL decode). String type UTF8("%EB%B9%B5") → "빵"

This table is about the section A1.6 Date/Time. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Return Value; row 1, column 4 = Example; row 2, column 1 = CMONTH(date); row 2, column 2 = Returns the month name of the given date.; row 2, column 3 = String type; row 2, column 4 = CMONTH(#2004-01-01#) → "January"; row 3, column 1 = CWEEK(date); row 3, column 2 = Returns the day of the week name of the given date.; row 3, column 3 = String type; row 3, column 4 = CWEEK(#2004-01-01#) → "Thursday"; row 4, column 1 = DATE([nYear, nMonth, nDay]); row 4, column 2 = Returns a date value. If omitted, returns the current date.; row 4, column 3 = Date type; row 4, column 4 = DATE(2004, 1, 1) → #2004-01-01#; row 5, column 1 = DATETIME([nYear, nMonth, nDay [, nHours [, nMinutes [, nSeconds]]]]); row 5, column 2 = Returns a date and time value. If omitted, returns the current date and time.; row 5, column 3 = Date type; row 5, column 4 = DATETIME(2004, 1, 1, 12) → #2004-01-01 12:00:00#
table_html:
Function Name Description Return Value Example
CMONTH(date) Returns the month name of the given date. String type CMONTH(#2004-01-01#) → "January"
CWEEK(date) Returns the day of the week name of the given date. String type CWEEK(#2004-01-01#) → "Thursday"
DATE([nYear, nMonth, nDay]) Returns a date value. If omitted, returns the current date. Date type DATE(2004, 1, 1) → #2004-01-01#
DATETIME([nYear, nMonth, nDay [, nHours [, nMinutes [, nSeconds]]]]) Returns a date and time value. If omitted, returns the current date and time. Date type DATETIME(2004, 1, 1, 12) → #2004-01-01 12:00:00#
DAY(date) Returns the day of the month. Real type DAY(#2007-04-06#) → 6
DAYOFYEAR(date) Returns the day number within the year. Real type DAYOFYEAR(#2004-02-01#) → 32
DAYS(date1, date2) Returns the difference in days between two dates. Real type DAYS(#2004-01-01#, #2003-02-01#) → 334
GODAY(date, day) Adds or subtracts a specified number of days to/from a date. Date type GODAY(#2004-02-01#, 5) → #2004-02-06#
GOHOUR(date, day) Adds or subtracts a specified number of hours to/from a date. Date type GOHOUR(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#, 2) → #2004-01-01 15:30:20#
GOMINUTE(date, day) Adds or subtracts a specified number of minutes to/from a date. Date type GOMINUTE(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#, 2) → #2004-01-01 13:32:20#
GOMONTH(date, month) Adds or subtracts a specified number of months to/from a date. Date type GOMONTH(#2004-02-01#, 5) → #2004-07-01#
GOSECOND(date, day) Adds or subtracts a specified number of seconds to/from a date. Date type GOSECOND(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#, 2) → #2004-01-01 13:30:22#
GOYEAR(date, year) Adds or subtracts a specified number of years to/from a date. Date type GOYEAR(#2004-02-01#, 5) → #2009-02-01#
HOUR(date) Returns the hour component (24-hour format). Real type HOUR(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → 13
HOURS(date1, date2) Returns the difference in hours between two date/time values. Real type HOURS(#2004-01-01 19:00:00#, #2004-01-01 13:00:00#) → 6
MINUTE(date) Returns the minute component. Real type MINUTE(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → 30
MINUTES(date1, date2) Returns the difference in minutes between two date/time values. Real type MINUTES(#2004-01-01 13:30:00#, #2004-01-01 13:00:00#) → 30
MONTH(date) Returns the month number (1–12). Real type MONTH(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → 1
MONTHS(date1, date2) Returns the difference in months between two dates. Real type MONTHS(#2004-01-01#, #2003-01-01#) → 12
SEC(date) Returns the second component. Real type SEC(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → 20
SECS(date1, date2) Returns the difference in seconds between two date/time values. Real type SECS(#2004-01-01 13:30:40#, #2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → 20
TIME() Returns the current time of stream execution in hh:mm:ss format. String type TIME() → #17:30:20#
TRIMDATE(date) Returns only the time portion of a date/time value. Date type TRIMDATE(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → #13:30:20#
TRIMTIME(date) Returns only the date portion, excluding time. Date type TRIMTIME(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → #2004-01-01#
WEEK(date) Returns the weekday number (Sunday=1 … Saturday=7). Real type WEEK(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → 5
YEAR(date) Returns the year. Real type YEAR(#2004-01-01 13:30:20#) → 2004
YEARS(date1, date2) Returns the difference in years between two dates. Real type YEARS(#2004-01-01#, #2003-01-01#) → 1

TIME() Returns the current time of stream execution in hh:mm:ss format. String type TIME() → #17:30:20#

This table is about the section A1.8 Information. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Return Value; row 1, column 4 = Example; row 2, column 1 = BETWEEN(val, lval, hval); row 2, column 2 = Returns TRUE if val is between lval and hval.; row 2, column 3 = Integer type; row 2, column 4 = BETWEEN(1,0,2) → TRUE; row 3, column 1 = DATASIZE(); row 3, column 2 = Returns row count of the current dataset.; row 3, column 3 = Real type; row 3, column 4 = DATASIZE() → 100; row 4, column 1 = EQSTR(val1, val2[, …, valN]); row 4, column 2 = Returns TRUE if all strings are equal.; row 4, column 3 = Integer type; row 4, column 4 = EQSTR("A","A") → TRUE; row 5, column 1 = ISALPHA(text); row 5, column 2 = TRUE if alphabetic.; row 5, column 3 = Integer type; row 5, column 4 = ISALPHA("A") → TRUE
table_html:
Function Name Description Return Value Example
BETWEEN(val, lval, hval) Returns TRUE if val is between lval and hval. Integer type BETWEEN(1,0,2) → TRUE
DATASIZE() Returns row count of the current dataset. Real type DATASIZE() → 100
EQSTR(val1, val2[, …, valN]) Returns TRUE if all strings are equal. Integer type EQSTR("A","A") → TRUE
ISALPHA(text) TRUE if alphabetic. Integer type ISALPHA("A") → TRUE
ISBOOL(val) TRUE if Boolean-evaluable. Integer type ISBOOL(1=2) → TRUE; ISBOOL(123) → FALSE
ISDATE(val) TRUE if date type. Integer type ISDATE(#2004-01-01#) → TRUE
ISDIGIT(text) TRUE if numeric string. Integer type ISDIGIT("123") → TRUE
ISIN(val, val1[, …, valN]) TRUE if val matches any of val1…valN. Integer type ISIN("BAG","BAG","Nice","Book") → TRUE
ISLOWER(text) TRUE if lowercase. Integer type ISLOWER("a") → TRUE
ISNULL(val) TRUE if missing/NULL. Integer type ISNULL(@NULL) → TRUE
ISNUMERIC(val) TRUE if integer or real. Integer type ISNUMERIC(1.2) → TRUE
ISSTRING(val) TRUE if string type. Integer type ISSTRING("123") → TRUE
ISUPPER(text) TRUE if uppercase. Integer type ISUPPER("A") → TRUE
MAX(val1, val2 [, …, valN]) Maximum of inputs. Unknown MAX(1,2,3) → 3
MIN(val1, val2 [, …, valN]) Minimum of inputs. Unknown MIN(1,2,3) → 1
SIGN(num) Returns 1 if >0, -1 if <0, 0 if =0. Integer type SIGN(-123) → -1
VARTYPE(val) Returns one of S(string), N(numeric), B(Boolean), D(date), X(NULL), U(unknown). String type VARTYPE("A") → "S"

Context:
This table is about the section A1.10 Macro. 
Title: You can use macros to reference predefined values. To use a macro, type @ followed by the name of the desired value. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Macro; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Return Value; row 2, column 1 = @FALSE; row 2, column 2 = Enter false value of bool.; row 2, column 3 = String type; row 3, column 1 = @NULL; row 3, column 2 = Inserts a NULL value.; row 3, column 3 = Unknown; row 4, column 1 = @ROWNUM; row 4, column 2 = Returns the index of the record currently being processed.; row 4, column 3 = Real type; row 5, column 1 = @TRUE; row 5, column 2 = Enter true value of bool.; row 5, column 3 = String type
table_html:
Macro Description Return Value
@FALSE Enter false value of bool. String type
@NULL Inserts a NULL value. Unknown
@ROWNUM Returns the index of the record currently being processed. Real type
@TRUE Enter true value of bool. String type
@VAR Refers to the variable currently being computed when generating multiple derived fields (usable only in multi-derived-field contexts). Unknown
@VARIDX Returns the index of the variable currently being computed when generating multiple derived fields (usable only in multi-derived-field contexts). Real type

Context:
This table is about the section A1.11 Other Fu n ctions. 
Rows: row 1, column 1 = Function Name; row 1, column 2 = Description; row 1, column 3 = Return Value; row 2, column 1 = GETDEFDATE(key); row 2, column 2 = Returns a predefined date/time value for key.; row 2, column 3 = Date type; row 3, column 1 = GETDEFNUM(key); row 3, column 2 = Returns a predefined numeric value for key.; row 3, column 3 = Real type; row 4, column 1 = GETDEFSTR(key); row 4, column 2 = Returns a predefined string value for key.; row 4, column 3 = String type; row 5, column 1 = GETROWNUM(field_index, val); row 5, column 2 = Searches variable field_index for val and returns the row number of the match.; row 5, column 3 = Real type
table_html:
Function Name Description Return Value
GETDEFDATE(key) Returns a predefined date/time value for key. Date type
GETDEFNUM(key) Returns a predefined numeric value for key. Real type
GETDEFSTR(key) Returns a predefined string value for key. String type
GETROWNUM(field_index, val) Searches variable field_index for val and returns the row number of the match. Real type
GETVALUE(field_index, row) Returns the row-th value from variable field_index. Unknown
LARGEST(field_index, k) Returns the k-th largest (excluding missing values) in variable field_index. Real type
LOOKUP(field_index1, val, field_index2) Finds val in variable field_index1 and returns the value at the same row in variable field_index2. Unknown
MOVINGAVERAGE(field_index, k) Moving average of variable field_index. Real type
MOVINGMEDIAN(field_index, k) Moving median of variable field_index. Real type
MOVINGSTD(field_index, k) Moving standard deviation of variable field_index. Real type
REGSLOPE(field_index, k) Regression slope of variable field_index with time as X-axis. Real type
SMALLEST(field_index, k) Returns the k-th smallest value (ascending order). Real type
